Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, watching my stepfather quietly sip his tea, his eyes distant. I knew I should ask him if everything was alright, offer the support he always said meant so much to him. But my phone buzzed again—a message from Brother Yusuf, a long-time congregant. He needed to meet with me soon, he said, his family was falling apart and he didn’t know where else to turn. As an imam, I was expected to be there for my community, to listen, to guide, to help them find peace. But as a step-child, I was supposed to be present for my parents, to check in, to show I cared. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, each demanding my time, my empathy, my presence. I looked at my stepfather, then at my phone, feeling the tension coil tighter inside me. I wanted to be there for both, but I could already sense that whatever I chose, someone would be left waiting.
